bioghist.p: George Vaux Sr. (also known as George Vaux VIII; 1832-1915) was the Secretary and Treasurer of the Swatara Coal Company. He was interested in Quaker history and records. He served as an unofficial correspondent for the Philadelphia Yearly Meeting with London Yearly Meeting, and served one year as the President of the Friends Historical Society. George Vaux Jr. (also known as George Vaux IX; 1863-1927) graduated from Haverford in 1884 and received his law degree from the University of Pennsylvania. He was active in the areas of prison reform and Native American affairs. He served on the board of the Eastern Penitentiary. In 1906 he was appointed by Theodore Roosevelt to served on the Board of Indian Commissioners. He became the Commission's chairman in 1913 and held the post until his death. George Vaux III (also known as George Vaux X; 1909-1996) was a 1930 graduate of Haverford College. He was Treasurer of the Indian Committee of the Philadelphia Yearly Meeting and Chairman of the Friends Historical Commission. Mary Morris Vaux Walcott (1860-1940), the sister of George Vaux Jr., was a commissioner on the U.S. Board of Indian Commissioners from 1927 to 1932. She was an artist and naturalist known for her watercolor paintings of wildflowers.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of Vaux family papers. Materials include: correspondence, reports, newsletters, and copies of legislation from George Vaux Jr. and Mary Vaux Walcott's tenures on the U.S. Board of Indian Commissioners; George Vaux Jr.'s commission for this board from Theodore Roosevelt; photos and negatives of Indian reservations; bound religious volumes belonging to George Vaux Sr.; financial records and correspondence from the Indian Committee of the Philadelphia Yearly Meeting; correspondence, clippings, and other documents related to the Friends Historical Commission and the 12th Street Meeting; and miscellaneous documents related to various Quaker topics and Meetings from the nineteenth and twentieth centuries.
